docs.lead_paragraph: As Congress continues to look for ways to pay for an overhaul of the nation's health care system, Senator Max Baucus has proposed a series of fees to be levied against various industry groups, including health insurance companies.

headline.main: Insurers Object to Fees in Baucus Plan

docs.abstract: The insurance industry objects to new fees proposed by Senator Max Baucus.
docs.snippet: The insurance industry objects to new fees proposed by Senator Max Baucus.

docs.lead_paragraph: Senator Max Baucus of Montana, the chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, said Wednesday that the panel would take up sweeping health care legislation and start voting on it in two weeks, with or without the support of Republicans.

headline.main: Baucus to Press Ahead With Senate Proposal

docs.abstract: Senator Max Baucus plans to proceed with his health care proposal in the Senate over the next two weeks -- with or without Republican support, and no matter what the president says on Wednesday night.
docs.snippet: Senator Max Baucus plans to proceed with his health care proposal in the Senate over the next two weeks -- with or without Republican support, and no matter what the president says on Wednesday night.

docs.lead_paragraph: To Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, the Republican leader, bigger is obviously not better when it comes to health care legislation.

headline.main: Republican Leaders Offer a Little 'Prebuttal' to Obama's Speech

docs.abstract: In advance of tonight's joint session, top House and Senate members take issue with the need for a vast overhaul of the health care system.
docs.snippet: In advance of tonight's joint session, top House and Senate members take issue with the need for a vast overhaul of the health care system.

docs.lead_paragraph: Gail Collins: David. So. About President Obama's health care speech
docs.abstract: David Brooks and Gail Collins discuss the various health care options that the president should push Congress to embrace.
docs.snippet: David Brooks and Gail Collins discuss the various health care options that the president should push Congress to embrace.

byline.original: By DAVID BROOKS AND GAIL COLLINS

docs.lead_paragraph: President Obama acknowledged on Wednesday that his hands-off approach to health care legislation had likely been a mistake and that he had "probably left too much ambiguity out there'' by allowing Congress to take the lead in drafting a bill.

headline.main: Hands-Off Approach May Have Been a Mistake, Obama Says

docs.abstract: President Obama acknowledges that letting Congress take the lead on drafting health care legislation may have given opponents an edge in the debate.
docs.snippet: President Obama acknowledges that letting Congress take the lead on drafting health care legislation may have given opponents an edge in the debate.

docs.lead_paragraph: In prime time Wednesday evening, President Obama's address to a joint session of Congress will be closely watched as he tries to regain control of the debate over health care legislation.

headline.main: The Early Word: Prime-Time Health Care

docs.abstract: The president's address is tonight. The Supreme Court hears re-arguments in a special session before its fall term.
docs.snippet: The president's address is tonight. The Supreme Court hears re-arguments in a special session before its fall term.

headline.main: Nation Cannot Afford Not to Stem Medical Spending, Economists Warn

docs.abstract: A study in the policy journal Health Affairs is meant to remind policymakers that they ignore the rising cost of medical care at their peril.
docs.snippet: A study in the policy journal Health Affairs is meant to remind policymakers that they ignore the rising cost of medical care at their peril.

docs.lead_paragraph: In President Obama’s proposal, an offer of catastrophic health insurance for retirees 55 to 64 would tide them over until they could get Medicare.

headline.seo: Health Care Bridge for Early Retirees Draws Fire
headline.main: Bristling at Health Plan to Cover Early Retirees
headline.print_headline: Bristling at Health Plan To Cover Early Retirees

docs.snippet: In President Obama’s proposal, an offer of catastrophic health insurance for retirees 55 to 64 would tide them over until they could get Medicare.

docs.lead_paragraph: Medical students are facing a decision that's not only crucial to their own future, but also to the entire health care system: whether to choose a specialty or practice general medicine.

headline.sub: A Decision to Specialize or Practice General Medicine

docs.snippet: Medical students are facing a decision that's not only crucial to their own future, but also to the entire health care system: whether to choose a specialty or practice general medicine.

docs.lead_paragraph: Interviews with doctors, patients and healers about the human body, its resilience and its vulnerability, in time for President Obama’s address.
